channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Facebook Says It Should Have Taken Down Kenosha Guard Page
item.description: Jacob Blake was shot by police officers in Kenosha, Wis., this week, prompting work stoppages in professional sports. The N.B.A. and N.H.L. will resume playoff games on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Stephen Maturen/Reuters
item.media:description: Armed men on the roof of a building overlooking a protest in Kenosha, Wis., on Tuesday night.

item.title: March on Washington 2020: Protesters Hope to Rekindle Spirit of 1963
item.description: Thousands gathered for a protest on Friday aiming to recall the March on Washington and the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.’s “I Have a Dream” speech.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wines and Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The protest, held at the peak of the capitol’s stifling heat and humidity, began shortly after sunrise as knots of demonstrators clustered in front of the Lincoln Memorial.

item.title: Clouds of Smoke are Blowing Misery Across the West
item.description: Wildfires are burning from California to Minnesota, leaving millions of people to cough and wheeze through the toxic air. Gathering indoors brings the risk of coronavirus. Is there no respite?
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: As hundreds of wildfires charred nearly 1.4 million acres of dry, overgrown fuels across California, and more across other states, doctors said they have seen a surge in complaints from patients.

item.title: Have a New Address? Don’t Lose Your Mail
item.description: If you’ve decided to temporarily relocate, make sure your essential correspondence and eagerly anticipated packages can find you.
item.dc:creator: A.C. Shilton
item.media:credit: Cole Wilson for The New York Times

item.title: Trump’s Strategy: Make ‘Wobbly Republicans’ Think Their Party Is Great Again
item.description: The Trump campaign wants to lure back moderates who believe that the president has lurched too far right and openly courted extremists.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald Trump speaks during the final night of the Republican National Convention at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: 14 Injured in Bus Accident Near Port Authority
item.description: One person was critically hurt after a New Jersey Transit bus struck a barrier on a ramp at 39th Street and Ninth Avenue in Manhattan, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch and Edgar Sandoval
item.media:credit: FDNY
item.media:description: Multiple people were found on the ground outside the bus and passengers were trapped inside after a crash near the Port Authority terminal, a fire official said.

item.title: In One Louisiana City, a Police Shooting, a Pandemic and a Hurricane
item.description: In Lafayette, La., frustration and fatigue set in after storms, a pandemic and now a fatal police shooting that some residents believe is being overshadowed.
item.dc:creator: Christiaan Mader, Rick Rojas and Will Wright
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vigil at the edge of the Shell gas station parking lot where police shot and killed Trayford Pellerin.

item.title: Humans Take a Step Closer to ‘Flying Cars’
item.description: A Japanese company said it had completed a manned flight of its electrical vertical takeoff and landing machine. Experts say the technology needs work and that it will be expensive.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.category: electrical vertical takeoff and landing machine
item.media:credit: SkyDrive/CARTIVATOR 2020, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Japanese company SkyDrive conducted a four-minute test flight of its flying car prototype this month.

item.title: C.I.A. Uncensors Memoir of F.B.I. Agent Who Protested Torture of Terrorists
item.description: Nine years after the C.I.A. blacked out parts of Ali Soufan’s book, the agency has finally allowed a more complete version of his story to be published.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Carol Rosenberg
item.category: Shibh, Ramzi Muhammad Abdullah Bin Al-
item.media:credit: Hector Retamal/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: “If you fight for the truth hard enough, eventually you will win,” said Ali Soufan, a former F.B.I. counterterrorism agent whose book was heavily censored.

item.title: ‘That Same Feeling’: Painful Memories in Kenosha Come Rushing Back
item.description: The auto plant closed in 1988, turning the Wisconsin city upside down. Now it’s facing an even deeper existential crisis.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Carlos Javier Ortiz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents of Kenosha, Wis., were horrified this week by a police shooting and the destruction that followed. On Friday, positive messages were painted on boarded-up buildings.

item.title: How the G.O.P. Stretched Hard to Defend Trump on Race and Gender
item.description: Never before has a convention by a major party felt compelled to call such a diverse array of speakers to defend the character of a sitting president.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Sydney Ember
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ben Carson, the housing secretary and the only African-American in President Trump’s cabinet, spoke during the Republican National Convention on Thursday.

item.title: Covid-19: Live Updates
item.description: Some in Europe fear a return to lockdowns as cases rise. The virus has pushed the U.S. school bus industry into crisis.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Program to Cover Uninsured Covid-19 Patients Falls Short of Promise
item.description: Some patients are still receiving staggering bills. Others don’t qualify because conditions other than Covid-19 were their primary diagnosis.
item.dc:creator: Abby Goodnough
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Michael Starghill Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marilyn Cortez of Houston spent much of July in the hospital with the coronavirus. When she finally returned home, she received a $36,000 hospital bill.

item.title: Your Coronavirus Test Is Positive. Maybe It Shouldn’t Be.
item.description: The usual diagnostic tests may simply be too sensitive and too slow to contain the spread of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tests authorized by the F.D.A. provide only a yes-no answer to infection, and will identify as positive patients with low amounts of virus in their bodies.

item.title: Biden’s Approval Rating, G.O.P. Recasts Trump: This Week in the 2020 Race
item.description: President Trump, during his convention speech, did little to acknowledge the coronavirus pandemic, warning instead of what would become of the country’s economy and “greatness” if Joe Biden were elected.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump during the final night of the Republican National Convention at the White House on Thursday.

item.title: Is Teleprompter Trump Effective?
item.description: Although most voters complain about President Trump’s often abrasive personality, Americans over all are actually far more likely to say they’re bothered by his personal foibles than by his politics.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: N.B.A. Protest Shows Who Calls the Shots in a Superstar Economy
item.description: Professional basketball players demonstrated the enormous power of highly paid workers with rare skills, but also their caution.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Ashley Landis-Pool
item.media:description: N.B.A. playoff games will restart on Saturday after players stopped games this week to protest the shooting of Jacob Blake by police officers in Kenosha, Wis.

item.title: Hurricane Laura Was Powerful, but Louisiana Was Prepared
item.description: In 2005, Hurricane Rita leveled some coastal communities in southwest Louisiana, forcing changes to building codes and attitudes. As Laura approached, the region was ready.
item.dc:creator: Manny Fernandez and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.media:description: A search-and-rescue team at a storm-damaged gas station in Lake Charles, La., after Hurricane Laura hit the region on Thursday.

item.title: Rival Themes Emerge as Race Enters Final Weeks: Covid vs. Law and Order
item.description: The national political conventions over the last two weeks set the battle lines for the election’s remaining weeks. Joe Biden is focusing on President Trump’s virus management, while the president is hammering a law-and-order message.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck, Annie Karni and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. in Wilimington, Del., in August. On Thursday, Mr. Biden accused Mr. Trump of “rooting for more violence.”

item.title: Dead Dolphins Wash Ashore After Oil Spill Off Mauritius
item.description: The deaths have added to growing concern that the spill could be disastrous for Mauritius, a tiny island nation off Africa’s eastern coast that is highly dependent on fishing and tourism.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Laura Morosoli/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Carcasses of melon-headed whales, also known as electra dolphins, were loaded into a truck after washing up in Grand Sable, Mauritius.

item.title: Jacob Blake Was Shackled in Hospital Bed After Police Shot Him
item.description: The authorities said an earlier sexual assault charge was the reason for the restraints, which were removed on Friday.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon, Sarah Mervosh and Richard A. Oppel Jr.
item.media:credit: Brandon Bell/Getty Images
item.media:description: Chief Daniel Miskinis of the Kenosha Police Department said he believed that the officers knew of Jacob Blake’s outstanding warrant when they responded to a call about a domestic dispute.

item.title: Bill for Trump’s Tax Holiday Will Be Due Next Year, Treasury Dept. Says
item.description: According to new guidance, employees will be on the hook if their employer decides to withhold payroll taxes until the end of 2020.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s executive order suspending payroll taxes for workers until the end of the year has sown confusion about whether employees or employers will be on the hook when those taxes come due.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: Vacation stigma
item.description: Travelers are being shamed for potentially spreading the virus.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Larry Pardey, Mariner Who Sailed the World Engineless, Dies at 80
item.description: With his wife, Lin, he circumnavigated the world twice on wooden boats he had built. And they always took their time.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: House Panel Moves to Hold Pompeo in Contempt of Congress
item.description: The House Foreign Affairs Committee cited Mike Pompeo’s defiance of subpoenas related to the State Department’s compliance with Senate Republicans’ investigation targeting the Bidens.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Mike Segar
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo has drawn criticism for challenging diplomatic decorum in pursuit of his political ambitions.

item.title: School Bus Industry in Crisis Because of Coronavirus
item.description: Industry leaders say it will be the nation’s schoolchildren and parents who will suffer, as they alter their lives and figure out how to replace a mode of transportation that was once a certainty.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Glenn Every said the school bus company he owns has lost $750,000 because of the pandemic.

item.title: The Trump Women, Trying to Help Trump With Women
item.description: Tiffany Trump, Lara Trump, Kimberly Guilfoyle and, of course, Ivanka Trump all took a turn at promoting the family business — for all intents and purposes, President Trump — on the convention stage.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Lyall
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiffany Trump, 26, is the only child of the short-lived marriage between President Trump and Marla Maples, his second wife.

item.title: Trump Extends Pardon to Alice Johnson After She Praises Him at Convention
item.description: The president, who previously commuted her sentence, said he saw her in the audience as he accepted the nomination for a second term and decided to elevate his action to a full pardon.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alice Johnson on Friday in the Oval Office as President Trump signed her pardon.

item.title: At a nontraditional convention, some sartorial traditions endure.
item.dc:creator: Evan Nicole Brown
